title: Klevs Inn

text: The name of the place has been spelled in several ways over time: Marthaklef (1351), Mårdaklef (1406), and Mårdaklet (1894). One interpretation is that it derives from Mördaklef (The Murderer’s Gap), referring to a battle between Danes and Swedes that is said to have taken place here. Until the Treaty of Brömsebro in 1645, when Halland became Swedish, the Denmark–Sweden border ran just south of Mårdaklev. This made the area both militarily sensitive and strategically important. The Ätran valley was a main route between the coast and the inland. At Klev, there was a border crossing with customs and a relay station, and when the border situation eventually stabilized, the inn was established.
Mårdaklev Church replaced an older wooden church from 1688. However, the preserved medieval baptismal font suggests that there was already a church in the parish earlier.

Klevs Inn has its roots in the 17th century – the business is documented as early as 1695 – and was established as a stop along the Ätrastigen route. The inn operated in its original form until the 1950s.

Three main buildings have been preserved: the oldest house, from around 1750, which originally served as the farm's residence; the main building from 1836, which functioned as the tenant's residence; and a third building that over the years was used both as a serving hall and as lodging for travelers – a place where wanderers could rest, eat, and drink.

Household examinations were introduced in Sweden after the Church Law of 1686, but in many parishes, records began only in the 18th century. In Kalv parish, which included Mårdaklev, church archives have been preserved from 1722. Unfortunately, this means we cannot trace who lived on the farms before that.

In the household records, the building is referred to as Kleven and belonged to Roten no.5. Two families consistently lived in Kleven. From 1841 onward, it is also recorded that the farms Högklef and Kullen belonged to Kleven, and Stora Höghult and Lilla Höghult were owned by Högklef. From 1849, Marielund was also owned by Högklef.

Conclusions from the household records show that many people died during the 19th century. Between 1813–1819, epidemic diseases swept Sweden, including dysentery, which during 1808–1813 claimed about 50,000 lives. Measles, whooping cough (pertussis), and scarlet fever were also common and particularly deadly among children. Influenza occurred as well, especially during harsh winters.

Since Klevs Inn received travelers and guests who came and went, it is possible that diseases spread to the farm through visitors. This shows that even small parishes like Mårdaklev could be heavily affected by disease and high mortality.

history.heading1: Owners and Residents of Kleven - First Household

text: Jöns Andersson (b. 1723 – d. Feb 11, 1787) Married to Britta Larsdotter (b. 1729 – d. June 9, 1807). Children: Anna (b. Feb 11, 1757 – d. Nov 14, 1828), Maja (b. 1767).

Jöns (Jon) Andersson was the farm owner in Kleven, Mårdaklev, and a central figure in local history. According to church books, he lived at Kleven from at least 1772, when he appears in the household examination records. The 1775 protocol also confirms that he was the farm's owner.
His daughter Anna first married Bengt Jonsson in 1776 and later Nils Bengtsson in 1791. Anna and Nils eventually took over the farm.

Jöns was the son of Anders Jonsson (d. 1741) and Ingeborg Mårtensdotter (b. 1683 – d. Mar 15, 1755) in Klev. It is possible that Jöns's father or grandfather founded Kleven or owned the land originally, but since household records began only in 1722, this is unknown.
The household also included two farmhands, Hans Andersson and Petter Andersson, as well as two maids, Karin Knutsdotter and Britta Andersdotter.
Nils Bengtsson (b. Nov 14, 1757 – d. Apr 29, 1832) Married to Anna Jönsdotter (b. unknown – d. 1828). Children: Johannes (b. Oct 24, 1794 – d. Jan 2, 1839), Bengt Carl (b. Aug 30, 1802 – d. 1873).
Nils married Anna Jönsdotter on May 6, 1791, and took over ownership of Kleven from his father-in-law Jöns Andersson. In the 1809–1812 household record, he is listed as the owner of the house.
His son Johannes married Pernilla Andersdotter (b. Dec 14, 1802 – d. Mar 15, 1840), and they had four children.
His son Bengt Carl married Marie Elenora Andersdotter (b. 1809). According to available information, they had no documented children.
In the 1809–1812 household record, the maid Ingrid Andersson (b. Aug 1, 1782) is also noted as living in the house. Other maids are mentioned but crossed out.

In the 1813–1819 record, Nils and Anna remain on the farm. Many maids are crossed out, and some have a mark indicating they died. Johannes also has this mark and reportedly died in 1839. At this time, a farmhand named Carl Johannesson also lived on the farm.

In the 1820–1837 record, Nils died in 1832 and Anna in 1828. Bengt Carl is crossed out as he moved from the farm in 1827. All maids had moved to other farms, and the last one, Ingrid Jönsdotter, had also died.

Johannes Nilsson (b. Oct 24, 1794 – d. Jan 2, 1839) Married to Pernilla Andersdotter (b. Dec 14, 1802 – d. Mar 15, 1840). Children: Johanna (b. May 14, 1822), Bengt (b. Apr 10, 1825), Wilhelmina (b. Jan 1, 1828), Anna Nora (b. Feb 14, 1833 – d. Sept 15, 1833).
Johannes Nilsson, son of Nils Bengtsson and Anna Jönsdotter, lived with his wife Pernilla Andersdotter in the other part of the farm according to the 1820–1837 household records.
After Nils and Anna passed away, Johannes and Pernilla took over that part of the farm.
The 1820–1837 records also show that many farmhands and maids lived on the farm, but several either died or moved to other farms. Symbols next to names indicate death.

In the 1837–1840 record, Johannes and Pernilla are recorded as deceased. During this period, Dr. Anders Andersson and Johanna Andersson lived on the farm, along with the maids Anna Catharina Larsdotter, Catharina Magnusdotter, and Beata Larsdotter, as well as farmhands Johannes Larsson and Carl Johan Magnusson.

Bengt Johansson (b. 1802?) Married to Brita Erica Gustava Johansson (b. July 27, 1818). Children: Adolphina Petronella Eleonora (b. May 1, 1847), Anna Natalia (b. Oct 7, 1848), Johan Alfred Theodor (b. Dec 14, 1850), Jöns Adolf (b. Sept 7, 1859).
According to the 1841–1844 household record, the children Bengt, Johanna, and Wilhelmina remained in the house after Johannes and Pernilla’s death.

During the same period, it is noted that the farmhands Anders Andersson, Carl Johannes Magnusson, Anders Andersson, and Johannes Bengtsson had previously worked on the farm but moved on. Their work was then taken over by Johannes Andersson, Johannes Larsson, Anders Olofsson, and Josef Andersson. The maid Anna Catharina Larsdotter had also previously worked on the farm but moved, and her position was taken over by the maids Catharina Magnusdotter, Beata Larsdotter, and Ingrid Christina Christiansdotter.
In the 1844–1852 household record, it is recorded that Bengt’s sisters Johanna and Wilhelmina moved to Kolsgården in 1846. Bengt remained on the farm with his wife Brita and their children.

The 1852–1861 household record shows that the family was still living on the farm, and another son, Jöns Adolf, had been born. At that time, Demoiselle Betty Christina Lundotter (b. Sept 7, 1821) also lived in the house – 'Demoiselle' is a French form of address for an unmarried woman.

In the 1861–1868 household record, Bengt, Brita, and the children Adolfina, Anna, and Jöns remained, while the son Johan had likely moved. Betty moved out in 1863, and several farmhands and maids came and went during this period. Additionally, a tenant, Peter Blomqvist (b. Jan 18, 1833), lived on the farm.
Carl Erik Lorentzon (b. Nov 6, 1835 – d. Feb 25, 1892) Married to Anna Catharina Svensson (b. Sept 8, 1837 – d. Apr 1, 1909). Children: Janne Ludvig (b. June 23, 1867).
Carl and Anna are buried in Mårdaklev's old cemetery (gravestone #393557).

In the 1868–1879 household record, Carl Erik took over ownership of Klef. He lived there with his wife Anna Catharina and their son Janne Ludvig. During this period, many maids and farmhands came and went, both in connection with the change of ownership and after Lorentzon took over.
The family also had tenants for a period: August Carlsson, Johanna Johansdotter, and their son Carl Alfred, who later moved out.

In the 1880–1895 household record, the Lorentzon family remained on the farm, but Carl Erik died in 1892. During this time, Lars Enok Lorentzson Hålberg (b. Apr 15, 1871), who appears to have worked as a general store assistant, also lived on the farm. The farm continued to have many farmhands and maids coming and going.
Janne Lorentzon married Tonny (b. unknown). Children: Märta (b. 1899).
It was the son Janne who took over the farm after his parents. He was titled as a wine merchant and owner of the inn.
In 1897, Janne married Tonny, and together they had a daughter, Märta (b. 1899).
In 1907, the family moved to Gothenburg. We have not been able to find information on who took over the farm after that.

history.heading1: Owners and Residents of Kleven - Second Household

text: Jöns Andersson (b. 1735) Married to Anna Larsdotter (b. 1746). Possible later wife: Ingegärd Christersdotter (b. 1743).
In 1772, Jöns was the owner of the house, which is also confirmed in the 1775 household record.
In the 1772 household, the farmhand Jönsson and the maid Anna Larsdotter also lived there.
In the 1775 household, the farmhand Anders Andersson, the maid Kersin Håkansdotter, and an elderly woman named Kerstin Arferidsdotter, 80 years old, were noted.
Johannes Jönsson (b. June 16, 1774 – d. 1821) Married to Annika Petersdotter (b. Feb 11, 1762 – d. 1821).
Children: Johanna (b. Mar 9, 1804 – d. 1875), Anna Persdotter (b. May 19, 1834).
Johannes and Annika lived at Klef but both died in 1821.
Their daughter Johanna married Peter Persson on Feb 16, 1821, and took over the farm.
Several farmhands also lived on the farm during this time, but many died between 1820–1821.
Peter Pehrsson (b. Aug 5, 1785) Married to Johanna Johnsdotter (b. Mar 9, 1804).
Children: Johanna (b. Nov 16, 1825), Anders (b. Jan 2, 1829 – d. Dec 22, 1831), Catharina (b. Mar 28, 1823), Anna (b. May 19, 1834).
In 1821, Peter and Johanna took over the farm after Johanna’s parents died.
Between 1820 and 1837, many farmhands and maids came and went on the farm, and some died during this period.
At the end of 1837, the farmhands Peter Andersson and Harald Christiansson, as well as the maids Pernilla Larsdotter and Katharina Andersdotter, worked on the farm.

During the 1837–1840 household record, Peter and Johanna remained, but Peter died during this period. The work was taken over by farmhands Bengt Carlsson, Johannes Eriksson, and Peter Bengtsson, as well as maids Catharina Andersdotter, Pernilla Johansdotter, and Brita Christina Persdotter.

In the 1841–1844 household record, Johanna and her daughters remained. Farmhands Bengt Carlsson, Johannes Eriksson, and Lars Magnus Andersson had moved, and their work was taken over by Anders Gunnarsson and Peter Bengtsson, as well as maids Pernilla Johansdotter and Carolina Johansdotter.
Johan Jacob Pettersson (b. Sept 23, 1827) Married to Anna Pettersdotter (b. May 19, 1834).
Children: Ida Paulina (b. Mar 18, 1860), Alma Josefina (b. Mar 17, 1863 – d. May 22, 1864), Alfred Hjalmar (b. Nov 4, 1866 – d. Dec 31, 1871), Lorents Malkom (b. Apr 1, 1870).
Between 1861–1868, Johan, Anna, and their children lived on the farm. During these years, many farmhands and maids came and went. Alma died in 1864.
Between 1868–1879, the family continued to live on the farm, and their son Lorents Malkom was born. Their son Alfred died in 1871.
Between 1880–1895, Johan and his family moved from the farm. During this period, tenants lived in the house, including Per Backman and later Emil Albert Jakobsson.
Bengt Swensson (b. Nov 1, 1787 – d. Feb 23, 1856) Married to Rebecka Larsdotter (b. Sept 24, 1772 – d. Aug 14, 1842), and later to Anna Lena Magnusdotter (b. Nov 18, 1818).
Children with Rebecka: Johannes (b. Oct 19, 1813), Sven (b. Sept 15, 1815 – d. as a child).
Children with Anna Lena: Lorentz Robert (b. Dec 17, 1843), Severina Mathilda (b. Apr 12, 1846), Anna Benedicta (b. May 18, 1849), Johan August (b. May 3, 1852), Johanna Gustafva (b. Oct 3, 1855).
Between 1841–1844, Bengt, Rebecka, and Johannes lived on the farm. Rebecka died, and son Johannes moved to Klef in 1843.

Between 1844–1852, Bengt married Anna Lena, who moved in with her son Lorentz Robert. During this period, Severina Mathilda, Anna Benedicta, and Johan August were born. The farmhand Abraham moved to another farm.
Between 1852–1861, daughter Johanna Gustafva was born. Bengt died in 1856, and son Lorentz Robert moved out.
Between 1861–1868, widow Anna Lena remained with the children. Daughter Severina Mathilda moved out in 1861.
Between 1868–1879, Anna Lena stayed with daughter Anna Benedicta. Daughter Johanna moved out in 1872 and son Johan died in 1879. Anna Lena worked as a schoolteacher.
Between 1880–1895, Anna Lena remained with Anna Benedicta and worked as a primary school teacher.
Bengt Andersson (b. Oct 9, 1835). Married to Anna Pettersdotter (b. Dec 14, 1834).
Children: Anna Paulina (b. Feb 17, 1862).
Between 1868–1879, Bengt, Anna, and their daughter Anna Paulina lived in the house, which was owned by Carl Erik Lorentzon in Klef.
Between 1880–1895, the family remained in the house. During this period, they had a lodger, Karl Petersson, who lived there from 1880–1882.
Casper Johansson (b. Dec 13, 1791 – d. May 25, 1859).
Children: Johannes (b. Sept 7, 1821), Lena (b. June 15, 1823).
Between 1844–1852, Casper lived in the house with his children and the widow Kristin Swensdotter.
Between 1852–1861, Casper died in 1859. The children moved out, but Kristin remained. In the same year, Peter Andersson moved in.
Petter Andersson (b. Dec 17, 1822 – d. Jan 2, 1894). Married to Anna Sara Andersdotter (b. Feb 25, 1829).
Children: Anna Carolina (b. Mar 16, 1860), Anders (b. Dec 13, 1863), Carl Johan (b. Apr 30, 1867), Ida Benedikta (b. Jul 18, 1873).
Between 1861–1868, Petter and Anna remained on the farm with their children Anna Carolina and Anders. During this time, their son Carl Johan was also born.
Between 1868–1879, the family continued to live on the farm. Daughter Ida Benedikta was born in 1873.
Between 1880–1895, the family remained. Petter died in 1894, after which his son Carl Johan took over the farm. All other children moved out between 1881–1889.
Carl Johan Petersson (b. Apr 30, 1867). Married to Benedikta Andersdotter (b. Jul 9, 1860).
Children: Ernst Alfred (b. Jan 22, 1891), Per Sigfrid (b. Sept 30, 1892), Anni Constantia (b. Mar 27, 1894).
Between 1890–1895, Carl Johan and Benedikta lived on the farm with their children.
Peter Månsson (b. Jul 11, 1796 – d. Jan 10, 1842). Married to Erika Kerstin Swensdotter (b. Apr 29, 1784).
Between 1841–1844, Peter and Erika lived in the house with the maid Christina Johansdotter. Peter died in 1842, but his wife and the maid remained.
Between 1844–1852, the maid moved out, and in 1851 Erika also moved to Stora Höghult. Abraham Andersson then moved into the house.
Abraham Andersson. Married to Catharina Carlsdotter (b. Apr 13, 1816 – d. Feb 8, 1880).
Children: Anna (b. Oct 14, 1843), Anders Petter (b. Jan 29, 1847), Carolina (b. Nov 27, 1850), Marie Benedikta (b. Jul 27, 1857 – d. Dec 5, 1862), Johanna Britta (b. Apr 27, 1860).
Between 1852–1861, Abraham and Catharina lived there with their children. Daughter Anna moved out, and two daughters were born: Marie Benedikta and Johanna Britta.
Between 1861–1868, the family remained. Son Anders moved out, daughter Marie Benedikta died in 1862. Catharina died in 1880.
Between 1868–1879, Abraham remained. The children gradually moved out between 1872–1880, and Abraham later rented a room with the Johannes family.
Johannes Andersson (b. Jan 10, 1831). Married to Anna Greta Svensdotter (b. Oct 13, 1834).
Children: August (b. Apr 4, 1861), Severin (b. May 23, 1863), Karl Johan (b. Sept 24, 1865), Johannes (b. Aug 28, 1869), Anders Ludvig (b. Nov 16, 1873), Klas Albert (b. Jan 16, 1877).
Between 1880–1895, Johannes and Anna Greta lived on the farm. The couple married in 1857 but moved here in 1882. The children lived with them during the period 1883–1895.
Johannes Bengtsson (b. Oct 19, 1813 – d. Jul 25, 1882). Married to Catharina Magnusdotter (b. Jan 9, 1819 – d. Oct 27, 1883) since 1840.
Children: Anna Regina August (b. Mar 7, 1852 – d. Apr 1, 1852), (b. Aug 2, 1853), Anna Maria (b. May 8, 1856 – d. May 11, 1880), Johanna Benerikta (b. Mar 17, 1862).
Between 1844–1852, Johannes and Catharina lived in the house with their daughter Anna Regina, but sadly, they did not get to keep the baby as she died within a month.
Between 1852–1861, Johannes and Catharina lived in the house with their children August and Anna Maria. The maid Johanna Maria Johansdotter also lived there for a time.
Between 1861–1868, the family remained. During this period, daughter Johanna Benerikta was born. The farm also housed the farmhands Carl Johan Magnusson and Bengt Larsson.
Between 1868–1879, the family remained. Catharina was noted as being illly, but survived. Daughter Anna Maria died in 1880. Farmhand Bengt Larsson moved away.
Between 1880–1895, Johannes died in 1882 and Catharina in 1883. Their son August then took over the farm.
August Johansson (b. Aug 2, 1853). Married to Anna Johanna Karlsdotter (b. Apr 25, 1853). Married on Dec 31, 1880.
Children: Alma Karolina (b. Nov 17, 1878), Anna Sofia Gustavsdotter (b. Jun 28, 1881), Jenny Katarina (b. Jul 27, 1884), Ernst Herman (b. Jul 12, 1891).

results.title: Coming after the investigation at Klevs Gästgiveri. Stay tuned!

more: Visit JugendHouse and experience a unique combination of historic charm and modern comfort. Enjoy coffee, overnight stays, or book a venue for weddings and other events.

sources.text: Klev Nature and Cultural Reserve – West Sweden Tourism Portal

Svenljunga Municipality – Nature Conservation and Parks
Klev – Hiking Tips and Nature Trail, West Coast Foundation
